(Neither Facebook nor HTC would confirm the report.) The phone will not make it to market for 12 to 18 months and is expected to use a modified version of the Android operating system created and released by Google, the Web site reported. While some online commentators questioned the wisdom of Facebook entering the hardware business from scratch, the AllThingsD account described the decision as about independence: "Google and Apple run the two major smartphone operating systems, giving Facebook little say over its mobile destiny."

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 23
summary: The Tribune Company, which is trying to emerge from bankruptcy protection, agreed to pay its former chief executive, Randy Michaels, $675,000 in a settlement stemming from his abrupt resignation from the company last year, The Chicago Tribune reported. The company will also cover $50,000 in Mr. Michaels's legal fees. Mr. Michaels resigned under pressure, following reporting in The New York Times that detailed numerous instances of outlandish, often sexual behavior by Mr. Michaels and other top executives. The Tribune reported that he had demanded $900,000, the pro-rated portion of his 2010 management bonus, arguing that he "was effectively 'terminated without cause,' which would trigger the payment under terms of the bonus plan." The payment needs to be approved by a bankruptcy court judge.In Tuesday night's Republican presidential debate on CNN, which was devoted to national security issues, The Caucus live blog took note of the higher profile of Representative Ron Paul, the libertarian from Texas, who often can be hard to spot at these seemingly weekly encounters. As Trip Gabriel wrote for The Caucus, Mr. Paul's campaign "had claimed after the last debate hosted by CBS News that he got only 90 seconds of air time," but Tuesday night he played a more central role, serving as a dramatic foil to his rivals. He clashed with Newt Gingrich over the the Patriot Act, and Rick Santorum over profiling of travelers, including Muslims.

headline: Fete Accompli | Nothing Comes Between Me and My Calvins and Marriage Equality
summary: Last night, New Yorkers donned their most minimal attire and headed to the Calvin Klein flagship on Madison Avenue to introduce Americans for Marriage Equality USA, an advocacy program that promotes "love, family and commitment" and the rights of gays and lesbians to wed. The event, hosted by the Human Rights Campaign (HRC), was buzzing with post-holiday excitement -- everyone catching up on where they went, what they cooked and who they shared it with. In a toast to the organization, the HRC executive director, Joe Solmonese, thanked New York City Council Speaker Christine Quinn. "The conscience of this fight is Christine - she brought it all. Her truth, her story and her courage," he said. Among those in attendance (and enjoying the tunnel of light sculpture by the British artist Nathaniel Rackowe and music by DJ Coleman) were such notable guests as the comedian Jerry Seinfeld and his wife, Jessica, the author Jay McInerney, the model Karen Elson and the business tycoon Ron Perelman. Because everyone there had marriage on their minds, T went ahead and asked some what commitment means to them:

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 29
summary: The Republican presidential candidate Herman Cain, whose campaign had already been stung by accusations of sexual harassment, was confronted with allegations on Monday that he carried on a 13-year affair with an Atlanta businesswoman. Because the story broke while Mr. Cain was live on CNN's "The Situation Room," he responded to the allegations by the woman, Ginger White, before they had actually aired on the Fox affiliate in Atlanta, WAGA-TV. According to The Huffington Post, the allegations "didn't come up during Cain's first segment with anchor Wolf Blitzer. That's because Blitzer didn't know about them either when the two men sat down." During that first segment of three, CNN producers began to see posts to Twitter that mentioned the coming WAGA story. "While seated during a commercial break, Blitzer then asked Cain about the Atlanta report and the candidate acknowledged that his campaign had been contacted about it and would be willing to discuss it on air," Michael Calderone of The Huffington Post reported. [Huffington Post]

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 30
summary: DealBook explains some of the thinking behind the report that Facebook (no relation) may be planning an initial public offering in the spring to raise $10 billion, with a company valuation of $100 billion. In short, Steven M. Davidoff, the Deal Professor, writes, Facebook "just has too many shareholders." When a United States company has 500 or more shareholders of record it must soon begin filing reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including audited financial information. Facebook is likely to reach 500 in April 2012, he writes, and most companies conclude that "if they are going to be subject to much of the regulation that comes with being public, they might as well just go ahead with an I.P.O. and get the full benefits of being public."

headline: Now Reading | 'DarkMarket'
summary: If style, per Gore Vidal, is about not giving a damn, then one might say cybercriminals have lots of style. "DarkMarket" (Knopf, $27), the new book by the T contributor Misha Glenny, disturbingly catalogs the capabilities of these nefarious Internet trolls - imagine, as Glenny does, that they could not only clog your in-box and steal your financial identity but attack your government, cripple your power grid or disable your national banking system. Still, the most common illicit activity on the Interwebs -  pornography aside  -  seems to be some form of personal credit card fraud. In fact, Glenny's title, "DarkMarket," comes from the name of a Web site where thousands of hackers coordinated the cloning and selling of credit card numbers and pins, often culled from illegally placed "skimmers" in A.T.M.'s and card machines. The site was infiltrated by an F.B.I. agent and taken down in 2008, resulting in many arrests.

headline: FDI in Retail: Another 'Reform By Stealth' Failure

Faced with politically unpalatable proposals, Indian politicians and bureaucrats often go quiet, enact reforms in the dead of the night and then pray that the opposition is either too lazy or preoccupied to react.

headline: China's Allure in Drug Research
summary: Drug research tends to follow spending. Take Merck's pledge on Tuesday to invest $1.5 billion in research and development in China over five years. Citizens of emerging economies are growing wealthier and living longer, while the fiscal health of their governments is robust. Merck's step suggests that the pharmaceutical industry's center of gravity is shifting eastward accordingly. Growth in developed markets, where drug companies make most of their sales, is slowing to a crawl. The blockbusters of a few years ago are losing patent protection while cash-starved governments are clamping down on the prices they're willing to pay for state-financed medical programs. In the United States, which accounts for more than a third of total revenue for the sector, drug sales increased only 2 percent last year, according to IMS Health.

headline: Back When Mother, Too, Knew Best

''The Donna Reed Show'' is seldom rerun, hobbled by its black-and-white photography, but its eponymous star is still regularly beamed back to mind this time of year with broadcasts of ''It's a Wonderful Life,'' the beloved Frank Capra film in which she co-stars with Jimmy Stewart, reminding viewers of her soft-spoken, wholesome appeal. The long-unseenfourth season of the 1958-66 series was released this month on DVD (from MPI Home Video), making it available for the first time to a new generation of viewers and older ones eager to become reacquainted.

The loans, called R.A.L.'s in the industry, are short term, repaid with a borrower's income tax refund. That would be Angry Birds, of course, but also the Kindle Top 100 Free best-seller list. Some of these books are out of copyright -- "Dracula," Jane Austen -- and some seem to have originated with Amazon itself. But at the top and interspersed all the way through are novels written by living if somewhat obscure authors. Romances, mostly, often with a Christian theme.

In this post I want to describe another reason Mr. Negri thinks Google+ provides a real edge -- and also present the point of view of a business owner who disagrees.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Rag & Bone
summary: "Not clean and pretty," is how Guido Palau described the tousled hair backstage at Rag & Bone. "It's quite rock 'n' roll. Dread-y." To create this effect, Palau used Redken Full Frame Mousse and Rough Paste before mussing and twirling strands with his fingers. The model Cara Delevingne loved the look. "It really reminds me of my festival experiences," she said of hot days spent at Nevada's Burning Man. This season, it's the same cool Rag & Bone girl, but she's gone on a trip further afield. "Patti Smith in India," said Gucci Westman of her makeup muse. Porcelain skin was highlighted with Revlon's Midnight Express and Flushed PhotoReady Cream Blush to contrast an eye covered in Illuminance Crème Shadow in Not Just Nudes and lined in black. Three textures: gel, liquid and a kohl, were used around the entire eye before the top lid was wiped clean with a Q-tip. "We wanted it to feel more downtown," Westman said. "Everyone was concerned that no one look glamorous."

Kline is the 17-year-old impresario behind TheRecruitScoop.com, which in three years of existence has established itself as a highly authoritative observer of the college basketball recruiting scene. His reliable reporting has earned him 21,000 followers on Twitter, and on Monday, his upstart site will enter a new phase. summary: Fox is the empire’s good son, but also its most toxic legacy.

headline: If the Ring Finger Isn't a Green Thumb
summary: NOT every bride or bridegroom has a green thumb, the desire to maintain a garden or even the luxury of outdoor space. But a touch of green is within everyone's reach. Low-maintenance terrariums or indoor cactus gardens make cheerful, lasting gifts. And cooks who enjoy fresh ingredients can grow herbs or harvest a crop of mushrooms just an arm's length away in their own kitchen. For newlyweds who do have a yard, there is a sequoia sapling that will grow (one to three feet a year!) with the marriage, as well as new chairs to decorate a patio or terrace. For couples who prefer to sit indoors by their coffee table, a new book of photography by the New York landscape artist Paula Hayes will be available later this month.

headline: Tax-Subsidy Rules Bode Ill for Affordable Housing in Low-Income Areas
summary: Many developers and affordable-housing advocates said they feared that the rule changes could make it much more difficult for projects to be built in cities.

headline: Jean-Baptiste Michel
summary: A French-Mauritian mathematician, engineer and researcher on what he’s reading and watching — and what he’s not.

headline: It’s No Tomato, but a Stalk Gets Some Respect
summary: Asparagus heralds the start of the season’s crops in New Jersey, and sellers are seeing more demand from customers and recognition for the state’s product.

headline: A Tough Road for Wal-Mart Shareholders
summary: Unfortunately for shareholders, a recent complaint filed by a pension fund is unlikely to result in any significant changes at Wal-Mart Stores.

headline: Many Competing Paths on the Road to the Phone Wallet
summary: As merchants upgrade payment terminals, technology companies are maneuvering to become the standard in paying with taps and swipes.

headline: Stock Trading Is Still Falling After '08 Crisis
summary: Even though American stocks have doubled in price in the last three years, investors and traders large and small keep giving the market the cold shoulder. Trading in the United States stock market has not only failed to recover since the 2008 financial crisis, it has continued to fall. In April, the average daily trades in American stocks on all exchanges stood at nearly half of its peak in 2008: 6.5 billion compared with 12.1 billion, according to Credit Suisse Trading Strategy.

headline: Out to Shake Up Music, Often With Sharp Words
summary: Jeff Price, the chief of TuneCore, a digital music distributor in Brooklyn, is a vocal gadfly who denounces the industry’s opaque accounting systems and sometimes insults companies he dislikes.

headline: U.S. Jury Hands Google Mixed Verdict on Oracle
summary: A limited and split decision over copyright violations by Google all but guaranteed continuing litigation.

headline: Few Clues in Killing of Groom at Churchill Downs
summary: The murder of a groom at Churchill Downs remained a mystery on Monday, as the police in Louisville, Ky., interviewed people they thought might know about the death but did not name any suspects. The groom, Adan Fabian Pérez, was found dead in Barn No. 8 shortly before dawn on Sunday, just hours after the conclusion of the Kentucky Derby. He was working for the trainer Cecil Borel, the brother of the jockey Calvin Borel, said Richard Brown, a spokesman for the Kentucky Horse Racing Commission.

headline: Volume Sales Slip, but Tyson’s Earnings Exceed Analyst Estimates
summary: Tyson said its income rose to $166 million, or 44 cents a share, from $159 million, or 42 cents a share, a year earlier. Analysts on average were expecting 39 cents a share.

headline: F.D.A. Staff Raises Concerns About Arthritis Drug
summary: As an advisory panel prepared to consider whether to recommend federal approval of Pfizer’s rheumatoid arthritis pill, F.D.A. documents raise safety questions.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Grimes Is Where Money and Tech Meet
summary: Morgan Stanley, led by its technology investment banking chief, Michael Grimes, has shepherded 28 technology initial public offerings in the past year.

headline: Signs of Support as Cuomo Outlines Plan on Disabled Abuse
summary: Politicians from both parties, and even labor, expressed openness to an agency to fight abuse of disabled patients.

headline: 50 Years of Barnstorming the Sports Beat
summary: Frank Deford’s memoir recalls a lost era of sportswriting, when players slept in fleabag hotels and stubbed out cigarettes in the dugout.

headline: Seeing Source of Electricity in Water Pipes
summary: Under a bill signed last week, New York City will study whether it is feasible to generate hydroelectric power from the city’s water supply.

headline: Keeping the Internet Neutral
summary: To reach the multitude of online services competing for your attention, you must first get through a bottleneck that is not competitive at all: high-speed broadband access.

headline: A Suit Over a Showman
summary: A legal battle between the Harlem Wizards and the Harlem Ambassadors, two show basketball teams, centers on accusations that a player was induced to jump from one team to the other.

headline: Atop the Leader Board in Fun and Nonconformity, Too
summary: Last summer Rickie Fowler and Hunter Mahan joined with Bubba Watson and Ben Crane to form golf’s version of All-4-One, a boy band, the Golf Boys.

headline: Poverty’s Poster Child
summary: Some of the toughest and most persistent poverty in America exists on Indian reservations, like Pine Ridge in South Dakota. But it’s not hopeless.

headline: How Silicon Valley Uses Riches to Reinvest
summary: After Facebook's I.P.O., people made rich by the company's success aren't likely to sit on the sidelines. Instead, The New York Times' Somini Sengupta reports, early Facebook employees and other successful Silicon Valley entrepreneurs are likely to reinvest in new companies, aided by what Bill Tai, a partner at Charles River Ventures, calls the "dense set of overlapping spider webs" that is the social fabric of the start-up scene.

headline: Life, Interrupted: Posting Your Cancer on Facebook
summary: When I learned I had an aggressive form of leukemia 12 months ago, updating my Facebook profile was not a top priority. After all, in the land of Facebook, I didn’t have cancer yet.

headline: In Backing Coty’s Bid for Avon, Buffett Takes Unusual Step
summary: Coty included a new backer, Berkshire Hathaway, in its higher $10.7 billion bid for Avon Products, an unfriendly takeover that in some ways runs counter to Warren Buffett’s preferred methods of deal-making.

headline: PGA Tour Keeps Exception for Masters
summary: Commissioner Tim Finchem said the policy of not allowing courses that discriminate in membership to host tournaments will be waived for Augusta National.

headline: Cisco Income Rises in Line With Forecasts
summary: Cost-cutting measures aided profitability, but the company warned that it faced “a cautious” environment for corporate spending on information technology.

headline: Why Is Everyone Focused on Zuckerberg’s Hoodie?
summary: Over the last two days, there has been a great deal of mud-slinging and hand-wringing about the significance of what Mark Zuckerberg, 27, the chief of executive of Facebook, wore when he went courting would-be investors in New York. Why the fascination and why did some take offense?

headline: Where Do e-Books Go When You Do?
summary: To my dear children: No, I didn't leave you my Kindle. But I did leave you access to my e-books.

headline: Subsidies Aid Rebirth in U.S. Manufacturing
summary: There is a quiet realization that American factories need subsidies to survive globally — especially to compete with Asian and European companies that routinely receive government assistance.

headline: A Revamping of Bing in the Battle for Search Engine Supremacy
summary: A Microsoft-Facebook alliance plans an overhaul of Bing in an effort to loosen Google’s grip on the search engine market.

headline: Facebook Is Killing Text Messaging, Report Says
summary: Apple’s iMessage, the free, Internet-based text-messaging service, isn’t the only thing AT&T’s chief executive should lose sleep over. Facebook is eating into text-messaging revenues for carriers, too, according to a report.

headline: Gay Marriage Bans May Come at a Price
summary: As North Carolina voters approved a ban on same-sex marriage this week, executives and business professors were silent on the issue; some say the state may regret the outcome.

headline: The Education of Mark Zuckerberg
summary: Facebook’s founder and 28-year-old C.E.O. will soon face the unfamiliar landscape of running a public company, monitored by a merciless stock market.

headline: What if It Weren’t Called Pink Slime?
summary: “Lean finely textured beef” is safe and nutritious, experts say. But a nickname of “pink slime,” combined with Americans’ anxiety about food safety, have sent it on a downward spiral.

headline: From Forklifts to Photography
summary: After a wide range of business roles, Jeffrey T. Housenbold now has an outlet for his passion for photography — as chief executive of Shutterfly.

headline: After Fowler’s First Tour Win, Talk of Winning Streak
summary: Rickie Fowler is three strokes back at the Players Championship after three rounds as he looks to become the first player to win consecutive events since Tiger Woods in 2009.

headline: Disruptions: Facebook’s Real-Life ‘Spidey Sense’
summary: Facebook is more tapped into the pulse of people online than any company on the planet; as a result, it has the inside track to what is becoming more popular in a way that its many competitors do not.

headline: Joe Weisenthal vs. the 24-Hour News Cycle
summary: One man’s ruthless, relentless pursuit of market minutiae.

headline: Facebook’s Purchases May Hint at Its Future
summary: Because Facebook tends to be tight-lipped about its plans, the company’s string of acquisitions may reveal a lot about the course it is charting.

headline: Vermont Towns Have an Image, and They Say Dollar Stores Aren’t Part of It
summary: Opponents say a proposed Dollar General store in Chester, Vt., would be the beginning of the end for what might best be described as the town’s Vermontiness.

headline: At a Small Weekly, Online News Comes With a Fee
summary: The general manager of The Rockaway Wave, which has had an Internet pay wall since 2003, says, “You shouldn’t diminish your news value by giving it out for free.”

headline: As Talent Flees to Cable, Networks Fight Back
summary: Broadcast networks are offering shorter seasons and agreeing to air serialized shows uninterrupted by reruns to fight “cable envy” among series creators.

headline: Business Aircraft Looking for Takeoff
summary: Analysts predict that the market for business jets will regain lost ground slowly and with higher-end operations faring better.

headline: Ally’s Mortgage Unit, ResCap, Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Residential Capital. the mortgage unit of Ally Financial, filed for bankruptcy on Monday, a move aimed at removing Ally’s biggest obstacle to its turnaround efforts.

headline: Pocket: The New Way to Read It Later
summary: The popular time-shifting service Read It Later is now called Pocket, with new apps for iOS and Android that allow a user to save text, video and images found online for later offline viewing.

headline: Red Flags Said to Go Unheeded by Bosses at JPMorgan
summary: Despite Jamie Dimon’s recent apologies about the losses, which will most likely be repeated on Tuesday as JPMorgan shareholders gather for the company’s annual meeting, regulators will scrutinize risk management at the chief investment office.

headline: Yahoo’s Former Chief to Leave Without Severance
summary: Yahoo’s departing chief executive, Scott Thompson, will leave without severance pay after being forced out over an erroneous academic record.

headline: Smule, Early Apple App Star, Finally Tries Android
summary: Smule, the software developer known for its musical apps for iPhones, has decided it will make Android software too. It would almost appear to be an act of betrayal, as Smule was among the first companies to highlight the appeal of making apps for Apple’s platform.

headline: Dot-Music, Dot-Sport and (Security Experts Hope) Dot-Secure
summary: The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann, is about to throw open the floodgates to new top-level domain names. While most security experts have criticized the change, one group sees an opportunity by creating what it says will be a secure top-level domain.

headline: A Ticket, 3 Taser Jolts and, Perhaps, a Trip to the Supreme Court
summary: Three Seattle police officers have asked the Supreme Court to sign off on their use of a Taser on a pregnant woman in a traffic ticket case.

headline: ABC Has 10 New Series and Is Also Playing Up the Laughs
summary: ABC is adding four comedies. It has to replace one stalwart, “Desperate Housewives,” and it will ask its promising new soap entry, “Revenge,” to fill the 9 p.m. Sunday spot in the fall.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook’s Growth Prospects
summary: As Facebook goes public, it has to figure out how to use its vault of information to enrich its shareholders.

headline: After Coty Bid Dies, Avon Faces Hard Slog
summary: Shares in Avon plunged on Tuesday after Coty withdrew its $10.7 billion bid. Now the cosmetics maker faces few easy options in its turnaround effort.

headline: The Challenges in ResCap’s Bankruptcy
summary: The Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing of Ally Financial’s mortgage unit, Residential Capital, has the potential to remove the company’s biggest obstacle to a turnaround, but this is a complex case with many moving parts.

headline: China Flexes Its Regulatory Muscle, Catching Google in Its Grip
summary: China is having the final word on Google’s biggest and perhaps most strategic deal to date — its proposed $12.5 billion acquisition of Motorola Mobility, the American handset maker and communications company.

headline: Engineering Tricks That Helped Facebook Win
summary: Facebook made a couple of unsung choices early on that set it above the competition, including bringing in a veteran who knew how to handle complex software, and making systems that could scale up without breaking — or at least, without many people noticing they’d broken.

headline: Facebook’s Prospects May Rest on Trove of Data
summary: As the company goes public, it has to figure out how to use its vault of information to enrich its shareholders.

headline: Prepaid Debit Cards: Here a Fee, There a Fee
summary: Prepaid debit cards are becoming more popular but can carry hefty fees, according to a recent Consumer Reports analysis.

headline: Google Broadens Its Search Vision
summary: With Facebook about to go public Friday, Google announced big changes to its search results. Many have predicted that Facebook’s “social graph” will make Google’s search results irrelevant. Google’s new search feature, the Knowledge Graph, hopes to churn up more relevant search results based on a new database of 500 million objects and 3.5 billion facts about the connections between them.

headline: The ‘Goodfellas’ Principles at Work in the Boardroom
summary: The issues at Best Buy serve as a reminder that among board members and executives, there shouldn’t be any secrets — and that loyalty to your friends only goes so far.

headline: Come the Revolution
summary: Through ventures like Coursera, world-class learning is coming at bargain-basement prices.

headline: A Russian Magnate’s Facebook Bet Pays Off Big
summary: Alisher B. Usmanov’s investments in the social media giant could be worth at least $6 billion when the company goes public.

headline: Verizon Sees Cash Cow in Shared Data Plans
summary: Verizon has outlined its strategy to make even more money from smartphones and tablets with two key weapons: shared data plans and its faster fourth-generation LTE network.

headline: Ahead of I.P.O., G.M. to Quit Advertising on Facebook
summary: The loss of $10 million in ad dollars does not represent a financial disaster for Facebook, but it is a public relations headache so close to the company’s initial stock offering this week.

headline: Soda Makers Scramble to Fill Void as Sales Drop
summary: Americans are abandoning carbonated drinks, and Coke and Pepsi are relying more than ever on the “flat” drinks and bottled waters.

headline: Daily Report: A Russian Tycoon and His Soon-to-Be Facebook Fortune
summary: In Wednesday’s New York Times, Andrew E. Kramer tells the story of Alisher B. Usmanov, a Russian steel tycoon who made an ambitious bet on Facebook in 2009, in the midst of the global recession. That bet is about to pay off, to the tune of about $6 billion.

headline: New Drug Trial Seeks to Stop Alzheimer’s Before It Starts
summary: A clinical trial of Crenezumab will focus largely on members of a Colombian family who are genetically destined to develop the disease but who do not yet have any symptoms.

headline: Ahead of Facebook I.P.O., a Skeptical Madison Ave.
summary: Despite the overwhelming level of interest in its I.P.O., Facebook is facing fresh concerns over its ability to attract enough advertising revenue. Will the social network reach its advertising potential?

headline: Rediscovering a Shortcut to an Hourglass Figure
summary: The faja, from the Spanish word for wrap, has become popular as a tight, form-fitting shortcut to curves.

headline: McGraw-Hill Announces E-Book Program With University of Minnesota
summary: McGraw-Hill announced a new e-book program with the University of Minnesota bookstore.

headline: J. C. Penney Posts Big Loss as 3 Retailers Gain
summary: The company lost $163 million, or 75 cents a share, versus a profit of $64 million in the same quarter a year ago.

headline: Skechers Toning Shoe Customers to Get Refund
summary: Federal regulators announced on Wednesday that Skechers has agreed to pay $40 million to settle charges that the company deceived consumers with claims about its toning shoes.

headline: Scuttlebot Special Edition–Facebook I.P.O.
summary: With Facebook’s initial public stock offering looming, the technology reporters and editors of The New York Times found an abundance of important and peculiar items about the company on the Web on Wednesday, including some early investors planning to sell larger stakes, the chances of meeting a new millionaire in the Bay Area and a comparison of Facebook with Google before its I.P.O.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Rebekah Brooks Charged and Steve Jobs Reimagined
summary: Also, G.M. pulls its Facebook ads just days before the social network’s public offering and the String Cheese Incident brings a guitar to a knife fight with Ticketmaster.

headline: Billboard Wars, Chapter 2 (or Is It 3?)
summary: The media company that accepted the conservative Heartland Institute’s controversial ad about climate change rejected one rival billboard but accepted another.

headline: How to Track Your Smartphone Data Usage
summary: Carriers seem to want to make it difficult for us to learn how much data or how many voice minutes we’ve used. That matters more as they herd us from all-you-can-use plans. The solution are apps that reveal a lot of this information.

headline: Facebook Raises $16 Billion in I.P.O.
summary: The initial public offering, priced at $38 a share, values Facebook at $104 billion, putting the social networking company on par with McDonald’s, Citigroup and Amazon.com.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Facebook’s ‘Global Citizen,’ and a Crossover Act in Spanish
summary: And network executives got a glimpse at the future this week, and they didn’t like it: digital video recorders that automatically skips ads.

headline: Saying ‘No’ to Picture Perfect
summary: A group of young feminists is campaigning against digitally retouched photographs in a teen magazine.

headline: Does Facebook Turn People Into Narcissists?
summary: Some research suggests that people who frequently update their Facebook status are more likely to exhibit narcissistic traits, but the social medium of choice for the self-absorbed may actually be Twitter.

headline: Ignore That Panorama
summary: This year’s show house is set in a modern Manhattan high-rise with sweeping views.

headline: Democratic Senators’ Proposal Targets Facebook Co-Founder
summary: As Facebook goes public, handing Eduardo Saverin a windfall, two Democratic senators unveil legislation to unleash the Internal Revenue Service on him, wherever he may live.

headline: Planet Fashion Gets Some Fresh Looks
summary: The artist Tom Sachs introduced NikeCraft, a small collection he did with the shoemaker, with his exhibition, “Space Program: Mars,” at the Park Avenue Armory.

headline: A Facebook Co-Founder Reflects on the Path Forward
summary: Eduardo Saverin, who left the company after two years, is assessing how best to manage the extraordinary wealth that will come his way in Facebook’s initial public offering.

headline: Facebook’s Missing Risk Factor
summary: Facebook arguably left one risk factor out. So DealBook submits the necessary passage, free of any legal fees.

headline: Problems With Online Bill Paying at Big Banks
summary: Customers of at least two big banks reported problems with online bill payment services this week.

headline: MojoMotors: A Virtual Middleman Between Used-Car Lots and Shoppers
summary: The site promises to save a shopper money above the lowest advertised price for any given car, but the discount is not necessarily substantial.

headline: To Dubstep or Headbang in New Jersey
summary: WHEN Courtney Pollack first heard that the Electric Daisy Carnival and the Bamboozle music festival would both be held this weekend in New Jersey, she experienced a moment of conflicted loyalties. It was a question not just of taste, but of identity, she said, as her love of electronic dance music faced off against a deeper, almost maternal tug of straight-up rock. ''My friends are torn between the two, a lot of us are,'' said Ms. Pollack, 24, of West Long Branch, N.J. ''I may like the music better at Electric Daisy Carnival, but I don't want to pass up a festival on the beach. I'm a huge electronic dance music fan, but I'm also a Jersey girl, so I love Bon Jovi and Gaslight Anthem.''

headline: After Buildup, a Modest Start for Facebook
summary: While disappointing new investors who were betting on fast gains, Facebook had a wide winner’s circle, creating huge paper gains for scores of early insiders, hundreds of employees and some stragglers who bought stakes recently.

headline: Building the Next Facebook a Tough Task in Europe
summary: PARIS -- The coffee machine spits out doses of espresso. Young men in shorts and loafers line up on a leatherette sofa, balancing Macs or iPads on their knees, discussing bands or business plans. Some speak French, others English. The lighting is subtle, the ideas sound bright. In a start-up incubator tucked away in an upper floor of an office building in Neuilly-sur-Seine, a suburb of Paris, several dozen entrepreneurs dream of building the next Google, Facebook or Zynga. It might look like Silicon Valley, but one thing is missing: the money.

headline: Facebook vs. Twitter
summary: In the world of social networks, Facebook and Twitter can be compared to the old children’s story “The Tortoise and the Hare.” But this race is not judged by speed but by the long-term relationship with users and their privacy.

headline: Facebook vs. Start-Ups
summary: Will Facebook’s debut on the Nasdaq have a ripple effect among start-ups, particularly those that are built on top of the social infrastructure established by the company?

headline: A Stem-Cell-Based Drug Gets Approval in Canada
summary: In a boost for the field of regenerative medicine, a small biotechnology company has received regulatory approval in Canada for what it says is the first manufactured drug based on stem cells. The company, Osiris Therapeutics of Columbia, Md., said Thursday that Canadian regulators had approved its drug Prochymal, to treat children suffering from graft-versus-host disease, a potentially deadly complication of bone marrow transplantation.

headline: Facebook vs. the Wireless Industry
summary: Facebook hasn’t yet figured out how to make meaningful revenue from mobile, the fastest growing industry in the world, but it has done plenty to create both opportunities and headaches for the wireless carriers.

headline: For Facebook, No Division of the Spoils
summary: The Internet was built by users for users. Rarely has this been so true as with Facebook, which is little more than the collection of everyone’s personal data. So why isn’t the social network owned by those hundreds of millions of users?

headline: With Lackluster Debut, Facebook Must Prove Itself to Investors
summary: The lack of a bounce in Facebook’s stock price on its first day might mean that investors are not comfortable with the high valuation for the social media site.

headline: Facebook Closes at $38.23, Nearly Flat on Day
summary: Investors may have really wanted to like Facebook, but many appeared to have changed their minds, as its stock price ends the day nearly flat Trading volume was extremely heavy, even as it was marred by technical glitches.

headline: Joy, Hacking and Nostalgia on I.P.O. Day
summary: What did Facebookers do to celebrate their successful I.P.O.? Why, take to Facebook and post photos and comments, of course. We present a sampling of some of them.

headline: Facebook Wins Oregon Tax Break
summary: Facebook’s successful I.P.O. wasn’t the only good news for the company. Oregon’s governor just signed a law that eases tax worries for Internet companies that operate big data centers there.

headline: A Facebook Drop for Zynga, Other Social Stocks
summary: On the day of Facebook’s initial public offering, when the glow of social networking is everywhere, why are Facebook’s peers getting punished in the stock market? Zynga and LinkedIn both saw their shares tumble after Facebook’s debut.

headline: A Week With Music, a Murdoch and Frenzy
summary: During television upfront week, NBC reached for Broadway’s stars for several new series, James Murdoch appeared at a Fox party, and USA and the CW tapped show fans to work up excitement.

headline: Preferred Style: Don't Flaunt It In Silicon Valley
summary: MENLO PARK, Calif. -- Wealth is here if you know where to find it. Fabulous home theaters are tucked into the basements of plain suburban houses. Bespoke jeans that start at $1,200 can be detected only by a tiny red logo on the button. The hand-painted Italian bicycles that flash across Silicon Valley on Saturday mornings have become the new Ferrari -- and only the cognoscenti could imagine that they cost more than $20,000.

headline: Facebook Buys Karma, a Gift-Giving App
summary: Shortly after the market closed on Friday, Facebook said it had bought Karma, a beautifully designed social gift-giving app. Facebook has been on the prowl for companies that could bring it more clout in the mobile space.

headline: ‘Princelings’ in China Use Family Ties to Gain Riches
summary: The authorities are eager to paint the fallen official Bo Xilai, whose family has a substantial fortune, as a rogue operator. But other officials’ relatives have also amassed vast wealth.

headline: Eduardo Saverin’s Billionaire Blues
summary: When you have been very close to something that changed the world, it is not easy to make the rest of your life align with that experience. And for more than one billionaire, the money only complicates things. As Eduardo Saverin says, “You are always afraid.”

headline: Bribery Case At Wal-Mart May Widen
summary: As Wal-Mart reported higher-than-expected first-quarter earnings on Thursday, it suggested in a regulatory filing that the scope of an internal investigation into bribery accusations had widened beyond the retailer's subsidiary in Mexico. The company reported that the audit committee of the Wal-Mart Stores board was examining possible violations of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and ''other alleged crimes or misconduct in connection with foreign subsidiaries, including Wal-Mart de México.'' It was the first public disclosure by the company that the internal inquiry could involve additional subsidiaries, though none was named.

headline: Free The Post Office!
summary: In the short run, it's not all that difficult to figure out how to stanch the bleeding at the United States Postal Service. True, its losses seem downright scary. In just the first half of this year, it reported losses of $6.5 billion, more than double the loss for the first two quarters of 2011. That's on top of the $25 billion it has lost over the past five years -- not to mention the $21 billion it expects to lose by the year 2016 if nothing changes.

headline: Zuckerberg Ties the Knot
summary: On Saturday, Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, announced that he had married his longtime girlfriend, Priscilla Chan. The announcement was made, of course, on Facebook.

headline: Nursing Drinks and Solving Crime in Paradise
summary: Jesse Stone has survived a lot, including the death in 2010 of the novelist who created him, Robert B. Parker. He is back on Sunday in ''Jesse Stone: Benefit of the Doubt,'' the eighth television movie in which Tom Selleck portrays him. Stone, who when he's employed is police chief in Paradise, Mass., was invented by Parker in the 1990s, and in this latest CBS film he's showing his age -- not physically, but as a cop-show construct.

headline: In the Undoing Of a C.E.O., A Puzzle
summary: When the activist shareholder Daniel Loeb confronted Yahoo's directors on May 3 with the possibility that Yahoo's recently hired chief executive, Scott Thompson, might have falsified his résumé by claiming to have a computer science degree, their initial reaction was disbelief. ''Scott is a forthright, no-nonsense, straightforward personality and a likable guy,'' one director said. But just 11 days later, Mr. Thompson's credibility with the board was in shreds, Mr. Loeb and two of his allies had landed the board seats he'd been agitating for since starting a proxy fight earlier this year, and Mr. Thompson was out, despite his last-minute revelation that he was battling thyroid cancer.

headline: Earmark Puts $17,000 Pans on Army Craft
summary: At a time of fiscal austerity, critics are pointing to the cost of a helicopter part made by a company whose owners are donors to Representative Harold Rogers, a Kentucky Republican.

headline: It’s Not Dick Tracy’s, but It Can Screen Your Messages
summary: A new generation of watches connects with smartphones and other devices to offer news feeds and e-mail, text and other alerts.

headline: Nasdaq Concedes Facebook Missteps
summary: The chief executive of the Nasdaq stock market acknowledged on Sunday that technical issues had marred the debut of Facebook as a public company on Friday, but contended that the missteps had not affected the performance of the company’s shares.

headline: Rangers Receive Air Support All the Way From Queens
summary: At exactly 10:19 a.m. on Saturday, three minutes after the free Delta-New York Rangers Fan Flight took off from La Guardia Airport's nearly deserted Marine Air Terminal and immediately banked hard left, an auburn-haired flight attendant turned on a loudspeaker and, with a slight Southern drawl, said, ''Ladies and gentlemen, we are beginning our final descent into Newark Liberty Airport.'' Her winking tone helped salve some of the sting from my morning: up at 6 a.m., surviving a narcoleptic cabdriver and the esteem-building exercise of removing my shoes and belt, emptying my pockets, isolating my laptop, and chancing a T.S.A. frisk-date. All this so I could observe how a group of die-hard fans (and contest winners) would react under similar circumstances.

headline: PGA Tour Moves Slowly to Speed the Pace of Play
summary: Kevin Na is the new poster child for slow play in golf, though he has never been punished with a stroke penalty for slow play.

headline: Peter D. Fuller Dies at 89; Had to Return Derby Purse
summary: The owner of Dancer’s Image, Mr. Fuller had to return his Kentucky Derby winner’s purse of $122,600 after the painkiller Phenylbutazone was found in the horse’s urine.

headline: Before Leaping, Listen to a Giant
summary: To Harry Markowitz, the father of modern portfolio theory, the Facebook stock hubbub is a yawn. He’d rather focus on a rigorously diversified mix of stocks and bonds.

headline: Do You Want the Good News First?
summary: A visit to the innovation hubs of Seattle and Silicon Valley stirred both excitement and dread. Here’s why.

headline: Facebook Gold Rush: Fanfare vs. Realities
summary: The small gain for Facebook’s stock on its first day of trading suggests that many professional money managers viewed all the hype as just that.

headline: An Entrepreneur at Heart
summary: The chief of Pixability drew on her education and experience in business, law and government to found her company, a provider of video marketing software and services.

headline: Will Disney’s Swampy Gator Be the Next Angry Birds?
summary: Disney is capitalizing on Swampy, the alligator from the popular Where’s My Water? game, introducing merchandise at Toys ‘R’ Us and featuring the character in a Web series.

headline: Is Insider Trading Part of the Fabric?
summary: EVEN before the news was official, it filtered out -- unofficially -- to Wall Street. On a trading floor in Midtown Manhattan, the squawk boxes were set to relay a market-moving bulletin at 10 a.m. This was the news: An analyst at the investment house was raising his assessment of Amkor Technology, a big name in computer chips.

headline: Numberplay: Meeting Times
summary: Welcome to Numberplay - the weeklong game of debate and discovery that also happens to be about math.

headline: Jury Is Seated in Rajat Gupta Trial

headline: Maturing as Publisher and Platform
summary: The Atavist, which helps produce multimedia storytelling for digital devices, has a content management system that has turned into a business opportunity.

headline: Numberplay: Meeting Times
summary: When do a clock’s hands meet?

headline: Cable Operators to Expand Their Plan to Share Wi-Fi Hot Spots
summary: Five of the nation’s biggest cable operators announced they would collaborate so that customers of one company can use the Wi-Fi of any of the others in public places like malls, arenas and parks.

headline: A Fight About Beef: Why to Avoid ‘Pink Slime’
summary: A critic of a beef filler disagrees with a Sunday Observer defending its use.

headline: Facebook Debut: Who Blew It?
summary: In assigning blame for a botched I.P.O., start with high-frequency traders, and include Nasdaq and Morgan Stanley. But don’t leave out what appears to have been Facebook’s desire to get top dollar.

headline: Clash of the Theme Parks
summary: ORLANDO, Fla. -- Pull down your lap bars: Universal Studios, the theme park chain now controlled by Comcast, is rolling out new weapons in its battle against Walt Disney Parks and Resorts -- and Disney is fortifying its defenses. Universal's parks have always languished in the shadow of mouse ears, and that will not change anytime soon. Disney has eight parks in California and Florida that attract over 73 million visitors each year, with summer the busiest season. Universal operates three parks, with annual attendance totaling about 18 million.

headline: Time Warner Cable Head Sides With TV Networks Over Ad-Erasing Technology
summary: Glenn Britt, the chief executive of Time Warner Cable, said he opposed services like Auto Hop, introduced by the Dish Network, as a danger to the system that produces television programming and distribution.

headline: As Facebook’s Stock Struggles, Fingers Start Pointing
summary: Much of the blame for Facebook’s initial public offering debacle is landing on Morgan Stanley, the lead banker.

headline: Facebook Shares Slump on Second Day
summary: Facebook’s stock closed down 11 percent on Monday, to around $34 a share.

headline: Cornell’s High-Tech Campus Will Have a Temporary Home at Google
summary: Before Cornell builds its new applied sciences school on Roosevelt Island, its first classes will be held in Google’s building in Chelsea.

headline: Professor Makes the Case That Google Is a Publisher
summary: A law professor, Eugene Volokh, argues in a paper that Google is a publisher, with First Amendment protection. But sometimes it benefits Google to be seen as a mere connector.

headline: From a Facebook Founder Comes a Way to Streamline Work Flow
summary: Asana, created by a Facebook co-founder, Dustin Moskovitz, is a shared to-do list for a company looking to make managing tasks at work a little easier.

headline: Troves of Personal Data, Forbidden to Researchers
summary: PALO ALTO, Calif. -- When scientists publish their research, they also make the underlying data available so the results can be verified by other scientists. At least that is how the system is supposed to work. But lately social scientists have come up against an exception that is, true to its name, huge.

headline: A Charity for Children of New York’s South Asian Working Class
summary: One quarter of South Asian children in New York City live at or below the poverty level.

headline: Daily Report: Europe Weighs Antitrust Case Against Google
summary: The European Commission warned Google to propose changes in “a matter of weeks” to its method of answering user queries, or face a potential antitrust lawsuit.

headline: Europe’s Approach to Antitrust Could Cause Friction
summary: Important procedural differences remain in the way the Europeans and Americans conduct their antitrust investigations of Google that could create friction as the cases develop. One of the most striking differences is that the European Commission effectively serves as a prosecutor, judge and jury in antitrust investigations.

headline: Zuckerberg's Property Status, Post-Marriage
summary: The new Mrs. Mark Zuckerberg might not have to worry much about money, but that doesn't mean she is automatically a billionaire. The timing of Mark Zuckerberg's marriage to his college sweetheart, Priscilla Chan, on Saturday, just a day after he took his company public, was certainly curious. Was he looking to clarify his net worth, which, with roughly 503 million shares, now stands at about $17 billion? And if true, many observers are speculating, did that have to do with the terms of a prenuptial agreement? The Zuckerbergs are not saying.

headline: Propelled by Apple, Markets Post Gains After a Losing Week
summary: The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index, where Apple accounts for 4 percent, had its best day in nearly five weeks.

headline: Europe Weighs Antitrust Case Against Google
summary: BRUSSELS -- Google may have abused its dominance in Internet search by promoting its own businesses at the expense of competitors, the European Commission said Monday. It warned the company to propose changes in ''a matter of weeks'' to its method of answering user queries, or possibly face an antitrust lawsuit. Search is the crucial tool that sends consumers to new restaurants and hotels, cheap airplane flights, and local services as varied as plumbers or baby sitters. In issuing the ultimatum, European regulators sent their strongest signal yet that they believe Google, which has long said its search results are neutral, tips the scales in its favor.

headline: ABC Requires Tether for Niagara Falls Walk
summary: Nik Wallenda said he was prepared to wear a harness when walking over Niagara Falls but would rather not.

headline: Rajaratnam’s Assistant Testifies in Gupta Trial
summary: The former executive assistant for the hedge fund titan Raj Rajaratnam described a call she received from Rajat Gupta on Sept. 23, 2008, about 10 minutes before the market closed.

headline: One on One: Andrew Keen, Author of ‘Digital Vertigo’
summary: Andrew Keen, author and technology reporter, discusses his new book, “Digital Vertigo: How Today’s Online Social Revolution Is Dividing, Diminishing, and Disorienting Us.” He says the tragedy of the Web is the unthinking acceptance that free works. “It doesn’t! The consequences have been very problematic. You have trashy products and you have corrupted content.”

headline: Facebook I.P.O. Raises Regulatory Concerns
summary: Regulators, in part, are concerned that banks may have shared information about Facebook with certain clients, rather than broadly with investors.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: The Facebook Offering
summary: A reader questions the Facebook business model, preferring the nonprofit example of Wikipedia. Readers are invited to respond.

headline: Recipes And Lists At Your Fingertips
summary: MORE than a decade ago, I was confronted with a crisis: planning a week's worth of menus and writing out the accompanying shopping list were gobbling up a humongous slice of my precious weekend. It stressed me out and caused a bit of marital strife. How, my new husband would ask, could it take me that long to make a list? My routine was this: On Saturday morning, surrounded by my cookbooks and recipe file, I would make dinner selections for each night of the week, then write a shopping list. While not unpleasant, it consumed most of the morning, and I had yet to even make it to the stores.

headline: Green Roofs in Big Cities Bring Relief From Above
summary: Turning the black tar roofs that cover our cities into green spaces is not cheap or easy, but its benefits to the environment would be great.

headline: Revenge in a Bowl, Served Cold

headline: Plane Diverted After Implant Claim

headline: U.S. Agency Approves New Gas Line to Run Under Hudson

headline: Band-Aids and Muppets Aim to Soothe Child’s Scrapes

summary: A daily capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.

headline: Google Cleared of Infringing on Oracle’s Java Patents

Barring any surprising last-minute judgements, a case that once held the prospect of shaking up the smartphone business will very likely end quietly.

headline: Buffett’s Goldman Deal Is Topic in an Insider Case

headline: The Facebook I.P.O.’s Potential Legal Exposure
summary: The success of shareholder lawsuits is likely to come down to whether there was information provided that needed to be disclosed to all investors and whether Facebook should have given more specific details.

headline: Theft Stalls, but Does Not Stop, a Project

headline: In Meetings on the Web, Owners Turn to Owners For Advice and Support
summary: On a recent Tuesday just after noon, D. Penn Moody, an Indianapolis optometrist and owner of Moody Eyes, was the first business owner to present a problem to his peer advisory group. Dr. Moody had recently expanded his vision practice and eyeglasses store, and he said he was having difficulty in balancing medical consultations and product sales. When a medical equipment manufacturer from Boston asked what his value proposition was, Dr. Moody replied, ''I think the value proposition is that we're the middle of the road.''

headline: The Canon G1 X: Big Sensor, Major Disappointments
summary: David Pogue spent a couple of months with the camera he was dying to love, the Canon G1 X. He has to say that he’s a little disappointed.

headline: Olympic Torch Turns Out to Be a Tough Sell

summary: We can harvest a certain fraction of a fish population that has been overfished, if we allow for the natural processes of birth and growth to rebuild the stock.

headline: Boundaries Expand When Marketing Links Dramas of TV and Web

The app, Air Graffiti, is being developed by AT&T but is still a twinkle in the eye of developers, who say it is a long way from being available to consumers. The app will enable users to leave location-based messages for one another in a street-view map. In the episode, Mr. Sutherland points his smartphone at a building and sees a message -- a series of numbers -- that was written by his son.

headline: Going Beyond Search, Into Fetch
summary: Microsoft and Google are jostling for bigger shares of the search market by including more data on search subjects.

headline: Small Investors Seek Answers to the Confusion of Facebook Trading

headline: Why Cisco Stopped Making Tablets
summary: Cisco has dropped out of the tablet business, saying people inside companies bring their own devices to work. It was called the Cius and, no, you couldn’t have been expected to know that. That said, Cisco may not be giving up on the Chrome operating system.

headline: Apple Strikes Back at Government E-Book Lawsuit

The company denies that it conspired with book publishers to raise e-book prices in a bid to give Apple’s new iPad a boost and to thwart the low e-book pricing of Amazon. But Apple put its objections to the case in somewhat sharper terms in the new filing.

headline: Mainstreaming Sex Toys Through Better Design — and Conversation

headline: New Orleans Newspaper Scales Back in Sign of Print Upheaval
summary: The Times-Picayune, a 175-year-old fixture in New Orleans and a symbol of the city's gritty resilience during Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath, has buckled under the pressures of the modern newspaper market. Advance Publications, owned by the Newhouse family, said Thursday it would scale back the printed edition to three days a week and impose staff cuts as a way to reduce costs as well as shift its emphasis to expanded online coverage.

headline: Hendrick Reclaims Spot Atop Nascar in Big Week

headline: A Company’s Stand for Gay Marriage, and Its Cost

headline: Immersed in Global Business

Coming from a small town grounds a person. You have to learn to get along with everyone. Desegregation was occurring across the country, but we had only one school in town, so there was no school to desegregate.

headline: Learning to Chase Online Word of Mouth

Gung-ho for hosiery, its fans are even posting sock images on Pinterest and tagging them on Tumblr blogs. ''It's Happy Socks Day at Fab,'' says Jason Goldberg, the company's chief executive and founder, as he checks digital dashboards on his iMac screen that continually chart customer sharing and spending. ''It's socktastic!''

headline: A Director With Irons in So Many Fires

Now, with Facebook's share price down 16 percent since the initial offering on May 17, and the lawsuits starting to fly, a seat on the board might feel like an affliction. Among the early accusations -- which the company has denied -- is that Facebook misled investors about its prospects.

headline: The Facebook Illusion
summary: The Internet economy isn’t as revolutionary as we had hoped.

headline: The ‘Invisible Art’: A Woman’s Touch Behind the Scenes

headline: Facebook Tries, Tries Again on a Smartphone

This past week, Google completed its acquisition of the hardware maker Motorola Mobility for $12.5 billion, which could lead to the search giant’s making its own smartphone. But another software titan might be getting into the hardware game as well: Facebook.

headline: My Walden, My Walmart

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Online Profits and Privacy

summary: Kasey Kahne, who won Nascar’s longest race for his first win with Hendrick Motorsports, ran away from the field in the final 100 laps after Greg Biffle had led for more than 200.

headline: A Doomed Romance With a New Orleans Newspaper
summary: In a city where not much of anything works, The Times-Picayune does, and nothing got print romanticists more dewy-eyed than the announcement of its reduced schedule.

headline: After Facebook, More Fear of Stock Market
summary: The financial industry had hoped that Facebook would rekindle ordinary investors’ excitement in stocks. But the Facebook faltering just added to a growing retreat from the stock market.

headline: Liking LinkedIn, While Wary of Facebook
summary: While shares of Facebook are roughly 24 percent below their offering price, those of rivals like LinkedIn, Pandora and Groupon are flat or even up over the same time period.

headline: Shots Fired, Pinpointed and Argued Over
summary: While more police departments are using a system that triangulates the location of gunshots, questions are being raised about privacy and police surveillance.

summary: The company has redirected the efforts of its entire staff of five: “Everything else has been put on hold.”

summary: Late last week, a presidential advisory committee urged President Obama to adopt computer technologies, including spectrum-sharing systems, so that better use is made of radio spectrum for wireless communications. How exactly would this spectrum-sharing technology work?

headline: You Can Change the Channel, but Local News Is the Same
summary: Agreements in which local TV stations share news operations are seen by the stations as a survival strategy, and by critics as a barrier to competition.

summary: If you feel like you are missing updates from certain Facebook friends, check your settings.

summary: Two items in the news last week underscore that the likelihood for a signature case arising out of the financial crisis is near zero.

summary: Carl Richards writes and sketches about the question he puts to people who want his opinion on the price of gold, the Facebook I.P.O. or the direction of the economy.

headline: Few Buy Chromebooks, but Google Keeps Pushing
summary: The Google Chrome operating system for computers has next to no takers among consumers and tepid response from businesses and schools, but it has plenty of support at the top of Google. The executives look at the time it took Android and the Chrome browser to catch on, and keep trying new strategies to build a market for the operating system.

headline: How Dewey Is Like Lehman
summary: Law firms and investment banks used to be traditional partnerships. Now banks are publicly traded corporations, and law firms are limited liability partnerships. Was this part of the problem?

headline: What We’re Reading
summary: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Name-Dropping at Gupta Trial
summary: To discredit prosecution witnesses, lawyers defending Rajat K. Gupta, a former director of Goldman Sachs and Procter & Gamble, sought to portray the Galleon Group hedge fund as a place where traders routinely boasted about their inside connections that did not exist.

headline: Drug Maker Seeks Protection Within Bill Favoring Generics
summary: WASHINGTON -- One of the few bills moving through Congress with bipartisan support this spring would speed government approval of lower-cost generic copies of brand-name drugs. But one company, with help from an influential former congressman, is lobbying to protect its most lucrative brand-name product against generic competition and appears to have had some success in the House, potentially altering the bill to make it more favorable for the company. The dispute highlights a central issue in health care, as makers of brand-name drugs -- many of which have struggled in recent years to develop successful new drugs -- fight to limit generic competition on their existing products for as long as possible. Brand-name companies argue that future drug development will suffer if they cannot profit from their investments, while generic companies argue that they can hold down medical costs.

headline: Weakness in Facebook Stock Adds to Pause in I.P.O.’s
summary: In the days since the highly anticipated opening of Facebook turned into a flop, the impact has become worse as would-be issuers have taken a second look at what they’re getting into.

headline: Have Patience, Stop Being Cynical, Senior Minister Tells India Critics
summary: People who are critical of the country’s economic performance aren’t doing justice to the India growth story, a political leader says.

headline: Even in Coal Country, the Fight for an Industry
summary: With the coal industry under siege across the country, an announcement that the operator of the Big Sandy power plant near Louisa, Ky., planned to switch to natural gas prompted an uproar.

headline: Technical Trading Issues to Blame for Facebook’s Fall, Meeker Says
summary: Speaking at the AllThingsD D10 conference on Wednesday, Mary Meeker, a former Morgan Stanley analyst, described Facebook’s initial public offering as a “financial tsunami,” but placed most of the blame on the string of technical problems that affected Facebook’s stock on its first day of trading.

headline: Books Under Glass: The Many Faces of E-Readers
summary: E-readers are more impressive than ever, and the prices have fallen because of improved technologies.

headline: Romney Campaigns at Failed Solyndra Factory
summary: The event at Solyndra, the solar-panel company that filed for bankruptcy protection after receiving $528 million in federal loan guarantees, represents a new effort by the Romney campaign to win over independent voters.

headline: Do People Like Being Featured in Facebook Ads?
summary: Facebook is turning its users into unpaid pitchmen in a type of advertisement known as a sponsored story. We asked Facebook friends who showed up in such ads what they thought of the practice.

headline: In New U.S. Uniforms, Stripes Are the Stars
summary: The new uniforms for the U.S. men’s and women’s soccer teams are bold and different–it’s all about the stripes–and it seems everyone has an opinion about them. What’s yours?

headline: At All Things Digital Conference, Talk of Disruptions
summary: At the D: All Things Digital technology conference, what’s reverberating through the conference is the change in the air in every aspect of technology. The word of the week has clearly been “disruption.”

headline: On Campus, New Deals With Banks

headline: Facing Down the Bankers

headline: Research in Motion, Struggling, Ponders a Dim Future

headline: Will More Restaurants Ban the Use of Prepaid Cards?

headline: A New Class of Cancer Drugs May Be Less Toxic
summary: Experimental treatments use an antibody to guide a toxic chemotherapy agent to cancer cells, limiting the toxin’s attack to the cancer and minimizing side effects.

headline: Pfizer Executive to Take the Helm of WebMD
summary: Cavan M. Redmond, a senior executive at Pfizer, will become the chief executive of WebMD, which is under pressure to bolster its share price.

headline: At Annual Meeting, Wal-Mart to Confront Shareholder Unrest
summary: The retailing giant holds its annual meeting Friday, celebrating 50 years in business but also having to deal with shareholder opposition to board members and some corporate policies.

headline: Chic in Review | Kate Moss Speaks! Sort Of …
summary: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Skepticism Greets Google’s Attempt to Deal With Censored Terms in China
summary: Google’s effort to improve user experience on its search pages while navigating government censorship is being greeted skeptically by some observers in China.

headline: Prominent Hollywood Producer to Assume Key Roles at Lucasfilm
summary: Kathleen Kennedy, a longtime producer who worked on films such as “Seabiscuit” and “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,” will become co-chairwoman of George Lucas’s film company, as Mr. Lucas moves closer to what he says will be his retirement.

headline: Two Locations Chosen to Annoy the Other Side
summary: Mitt Romney used Solyndra’s headquarters to emphasize the Obama administration’s failings, while an Obama aide took his message to Mr. Romney’s former workplace in Massachusetts.

headline: On Facebook, ‘Likes’ Become Ads
summary: Many companies pay Facebook to generate ads when users click to “like” their brands or reference them in some other way.

headline: Facebook: The New Danaher, Apco, Precision Castparts, Raven Industries or HollyFrontier?
summary: Many of the best-performing stocks of the last 30 years are those of companies that most people have never heard of. And it’s awfully hard to pick them out before they begin their run.

headline: As Lockup Expires, Groupon’s Shares Plunge
summary: Shares in the online coupon giant tumbled as much as 10 percent on Friday, and by midafternoon remained mired at about $9.65 a share, as a lockup on insider selling expired.

headline: Turning a Charity Symbol Into a Corporate Logo
summary: The documentary “Pink Ribbons, Inc.” examines the link between breast cancer research fund-raising and profits for the cause’s corporate sponsors.

headline: The Annual Shareholders’ Meeting for Wal-Mart, Like Its Stock, Is Buoyant
summary: At the retailer’s annual meeting, executives made a point of addressing concerns raised by a report that a bribery inquiry at its Mexican affiliate had been suppressed.

headline: A 4-Year-Old Filly Is Safe, and Sound
summary: A New York-bred filly that escaped horse slaughter is not sick; she is healthy and sound. She is not old and feeble; she is young and scopey. She is far from dangerous; according to her former trainer she is a “sweetheart.”

headline: In Land of Gas Drilling, Battle for Water That Doesn’t Reek or Fizz
summary: In a rural pocket of Wyoming, residents have long complained of unsafe water, and as they await definitive scientific testing, many blame nearby hydraulic fracturing.

headline: Exposing Drug Secrets, From a Well-Guarded Bunker
summary: After 17 years reporting on Paraguay’s drug trade, Cándido Figueredo has bodyguards on his porch and a handgun always within reach — a natural response to constant death threats.

headline: Ferrying a Drug Into a Cancer Cell
summary: Investigators released preliminary results from a clinical trial of T-DM1, a drug that targets and kills a type of cell that appears in some breast cancers.

headline: After the Crowds Leave the Track, Who Keeps You Company?
summary: Goats, ponies, monkeys, dogs, sheep, rats, roosters, rabbits and cats have all been known to be companions of thoroughbreds throughout the nation. But at Churchill Downs, it is the cats who serve as ambassadors and companions for the humans who sometimes need a friend.

headline: Picking Stocks After Facebook
summary: Buying an individual company’s stock is a wager on an unknowable future, as Facebook investors will tell you, and it can take decades before you know if you have a winner.

headline: Wall Street and the Average Reader
summary: Small investors could have used more red flags during the Facebook I.P.O. frenzy.

headline: A Military Regimen: Bring the Pain
summary: Every year, CrossFit gyms worldwide hold the Memorial Day Murph, a workout named for a serviceman killed in Afghanistan that is exquisitely intense, and simple.

headline: Xbox Gives Microsoft a Head Start in the Battle for Every Screen

headline: The Innovation Whiteboard Winners
summary: The four best personal innovations from our readers, as selected by our panel of experts.

headline: Events in Connecticut
summary: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.

headline: In Study, Drug Delays Worsening of Breast Cancer, With Fewer Side Effects
