headline: Craig Venter’s Bugs Might Save the World
summary: The controversial scientist is convinced that the planet’s biggest problems can be solved by its tiniest organisms. It’s just a matter of creating the right ones.

headline: How Big Data Gets Real
summary: Big Data is moving up a classic modern curve, from discovery to science, and on to engineering and mass use. We are not as far along as a lot of people selling the boom would have you believe, but lots of good businesses are being built that will make a revolution.

headline: Attacking Amazon, Authors Group Urges Opposition to E-Book Settlement
summary: The Authors Guild is encouraging its 8,500 members to submit comments against the proposed settlement between the Department of Justice and three large publishers. The settlement, the guild argues, will only benefit Amazon.

headline: A $1 Cigarette Tax Starts a $47 Million Brawl in California
summary: Health groups are pushing a ballot initiative to impose a $1-a-pack tax, provoking a storm of advertisements to defeat the biggest threat the industry has faced in the state in a decade.

headline: With Boos and Solyndra, Romney Plays Offense
summary: The Romney team plans to double down on its strategy of trying to keep President Obama on the defensive by refusing to let the focus stray from the struggles of average Americans.

headline: Blankfein Takes the Stand in an Insider Trading Case
summary: The third week of the trial of Rajat K. Gupta, who has been charged with leaking corporate secrets about Goldman Sachs, began with the testimony of the bank’s chief executive.

headline: Newspapers Cut Days From Publishing Week
summary: Some daily newspapers are cutting printing and delivery schedules and shifting their emphasis to the Web, but industry analysts warned that such moves might alienate once-loyal readers.

headline: Your Tech Questions, Answered: Part 1
summary: Sam Grobart, writer of the new tech-help column Tool Kit, answers readers’ questions posted online.

headline: Silicon Valley as the New Hollywood
summary: As is evident by the recent coverage in the mainstream gossip press, technology is no longer just a technology story.

headline: Goldman Sachs Cuts a Little Deeper
summary: The Wall Street firm laid off about 50 people last week, a number of them managing directors, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Fisker Recalls 19 Additional Karma Sedans for Fire Hazard
summary: The action widened a recall undertaken in December last year, in which 239 units of the plug-in hybrid sedan were recalled.

headline: Cisco’s Strategic Box
summary: Cisco has “a once in a decade platform.” It is a machine that handles 10 times as much mobile Internet traffic as current devices, and pays attention to different kinds of mobile data – a Facebook app on a phone acts differently from a YouTube video. Just as important is what it says about Cisco’s battle to stay meaningful.

headline: Disney Limits Junk-Food Ads
summary: Maybe it takes a powerful corporation to take on powerful corporations.

headline: As Google Bets on Mobile Office, Microsoft Waits
summary: Google has acquired Quickoffice, a start-up that makes a set of applications for iPads and Android tablets that let people open and edit Microsoft Office files. The deal will put additional pressure on Microsoft to release a version of Office for the iPad.

headline: At Made in NY Awards, Kickstarter Shares Honors With Streep and De Niro
summary: The awards, which were handed out Monday night at Gracie Mansion by the mayor, recognized people and companies for their achievements in “making it” in New York.

headline: Links While Driving Through Pocatello
summary: Your weekly roundup, dispatched from Pocatello, Idaho.

headline: Your Tech Questions, Answered: Part 4
summary: Sam Grobart, writer of the new tech-help column Tool Kit, answers readers’ questions posted online.

headline: Wal-Mart Vote Shows Rise in Shareholder Unrest
summary: Shareholders voting at last week’s annual meeting registered a spike in dissatisfaction with Wal-Mart Stores compared to last year, according to the company’s vote tally.

headline: Is Android Having a Bad Year?
summary: For some time now, Google’s Android system has been number one in terms of the quantity of devices that use the software. But recent statistics suggest that the almighty robot has been losing steam in the United States.

headline: Facebook Advisers Propose Ways to Allow Tweens on the Site Officially
summary: What should Facebook do to safely and legally let children under 13 use the site? Its advisers offer a wish list that includes an advertisement-free environment — a costly proposition for Facebook — and a requirement that children “friend” their parents on Facebook, so that they can see what is posted.

headline: MF Global and the Risks Looming in the Repo Market
summary: MF Global’s crippling bets were only possible because the brokerage firm was able to borrow voraciously in a debt market that also played a big role in the collapses of Lehman Brothers and Bear Stearns.

headline: How Jellio Is Solving Its Manufacturing Problems
summary: The maker of quirky home furnishings will continue to make some products locally and has found a way to produce in China, too.

headline: How Can Facebook Safely Add Under-13s?
summary: If Facebook opens up to children under 13, how can it do the job right?

headline: Airtime Adds to a Growing Choice of Video Chat Services
summary: Airtime, a live video chat service designed by Sean Parker and Shawn Fanning, the founders of Napster, hopes to recreate the spontaneity of the 1990s AOL chat rooms.

headline: Kenneth Cole’s Board Approves Management Buyout
summary: The board of Kenneth Cole Productions said on Wednesday that it had accepted a takeover offer by the shoe and clothing maker’s founder of $15.25 a share, or about $279 million.

headline: At Best Buy, Lumia Is Selling O.K. but More Slowly Than Android
summary: Nokia and AT&T have aggressively promoted the new Lumia 900 smartphone with a big marketing campaign, but at Best Buy, Lumia sales still pale in comparison to the hottest Android phones, an executive there says.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Warren Buffett Likes Newspapers, and Barbara Walters Apologizes
summary: Also, a big deal involving Taylor Swift will finally give labels and performers a cut of radio revenue.

headline: Cricket to Offer a No-Contract iPhone
summary: Cricket Wireless will soon begin offering an iPhone with a no-contract plan. Will it be a good deal?

headline: Two HTC One Phones, Both Pleasing
summary: The HTC One series phones might not be showy, but they are as pleasing to use as they are understated.

headline: Gupta Trial Judge Reprimands Law Student Spectator
summary: Judge Jed S. Rakoff asked a law student attending the insider trading trial of Rajat K. Gupta to stop sending him letters about the case.

headline: Google Schools Apple on Maps
summary: Apple is expected to dump Google Maps from its operating system, in favor of its own product. In response, Google is showing off how much it has done in maps, and how many features it has. The message to Apple is, this will cost more and take longer than you think.

headline: Saavn, Online Jukebox of Indian Music, Attracts Millions
summary: The free music streaming website has devotional and classical music, as well as Bollywood hits.

headline: Blogging a Day Devoted to Summer Reading
summary: Post your thoughts, recommendations, memories, tips or musings about summer reading on Twitter. We’ll be following and highlighting our favorite posts all day.

headline: Bachelorville’s Big Fish
summary: Mark Zuckerberg is now taken, but Silicon Valley’s dating pool is still well stocked with eligible singles.

headline: Lovely Flies, and Flies in Love
summary: Spring Time: In Corson’s Brook Woods on Staten Island, we are discovering a rich diversity of native flies, with nary a domestic pest in sight.

headline: The Untraditional Origins of a New Southern Comfort Ad
summary: Like Dannon before it, Southern Comfort is running commercials created through a crowd-sourcing initiative rather than by a traditional advertising agency.

headline: Former Card Counter’s New Start-Up Helps Measure Productivity
summary: Jeff Ma, an entrepreneur and member of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Blackjack Team that learned how to count cards in Las Vegas casinos, has started a new company that monitors employees to make them more productive. It’s not the watching that makes engineers better, but the measurement of their work that does the trick, he says.

headline: As Best Buy Founder Leaves, Thoughts of a Leveraged Buyout Re-emerge
summary: With the founder of Best Buy announcing on Thursday that he was resigning and potentially selling off his 20.1 percent stake in the company, many have been wondering whether the beleaguered electronics retailer may be sold.

headline: Apple Buddies Up With Cheaper Wireless Partners for iPhone
summary: Sprint said the iPhone would become available this month on Virgin Mobile USA, its service for prepaid plans, where customers pay for the service as they use it. The cost will be considerably less than the fees contract customers pay monthly to use an iPhone — once you get past the upfront price of the phone itself.

headline: IDC Says Nokia Shipped 2.2 Million Lumia Phones Last Quarter
summary: Nokia’s new Lumia smartphones are widely regarded as the Finnish handset maker’s last stand before it cedes the smartphone battle to Apple and Google. But how are the phones selling? One estimate suggests that shipments so far are relatively small.

headline: App Smart Extra: What Apple and Google Get Right
summary: App stores need better search engines, yes, but there is a lot that Apple and Google are doing right. Apple for vetting apps and highlighting good ones; Google for its Maps, Translate and SkyMap apps are still better than any competitors.

headline: Companies Try to Create Room on Radio Spectrum
summary: Technology that allows the sharing of frequencies is getting new backing as smartphones and tablets put greater demand on available bands.

headline: Once-Reticent Investors Join Shareholder Revolts
summary: Proxy season is traditionally dominated by well-known activist investors, but this year has been different with mutual funds and other institutional investors applying more pressure to corporate boards.

headline: Postcards From the Resort Collections
summary: On Wednesday, Mr. Elbaz joined other designers in the long march that is resort, that in-between season that provides stores with clothes around the time you’re carving the turkey.

headline: Predicting the Rise and Rise of 3-D
summary: Movies shot in 3-D are expensive, computational nightmares. And nobody in the audience looks good in those glasses. Jeffrey Katzenberg, the head of DreamWorks Animation, is still committed. DreamWorks has done all of its films in a 3-D version since 2009. He says the technology will improve. So will moving past the days of “Evil Bong 3-D.”

headline: Home 3-D Scans Made Cheap
summary: Soon handheld 3-D cameras may cost less than $1,000, sparking a boom in visualization. A Russian mathematician has worked out ways to display the depth and texture of the world by projecting grids of light on things.

headline: Detail by Detail, Gupta’s Lawyer Deconstructs Goldman Testimony
summary: During a second-day questioning of Lloyd C. Blankfein, Goldman’s chief executive, Rajat K. Gupta’s defense lawyer worked hard to turn facts toward his client’s advantage.

headline: Genentech Wins Approval for New Breast Cancer Drug
summary: The drug Perjeta is meant to be used with the company’s drug called Herceptin to treat the disease its advanced stages.

headline: Swiss Court Orders Modifications to Google Street View
summary: Google maintained its right to document residential streets with its Street View technology, but it must blur out sensitive facilities and notify communities in advance.

headline: Another Shoe Drops on Facebook
summary: A reader whose Facebook account was hacked wasn’t happy with the company’s efforts to assist, so he asked the Haggler for help.

headline: How Banks Could Return the Favor
summary: State and local governments looking to refinance bonds are stuck in Wall Street swap deals with high interest rates — so why not save some public money?

headline: Gupta Won’t Testify at His Insider Trading Trial
summary: The decision represents an about-face for Rajat K. Gupta, a former Goldman Sachs director. Late Friday, his lawyer said it was “highly likely” that he would testify.

headline: David M. Helpern, Chief of Joan & David Apparel Brand, Dies at 94
summary: Mr. Helpern, the chief executive of the business, and his wife, the designer and creative director, built their company into a retail preserve of high-quality, moderately priced stylishness.

headline: The Algorithm Didn’t Like My Essay
summary: Sophisticated software holds promise for making the grading of student essays more efficient — and it wouldn’t entirely replace human teachers.

headline: Nurturing a Baby and a Start-Up Business
summary: Some women are combining the dual challenges of motherhood and start-up companies — dispelling the image of the tech entrepreneur as a single, usually male, wunderkind.

headline: When You Write a Report Card, Explain the Grades
summary: Laura Yecies of SugarSync, an online storage service, says performance evaluations need to offer positive feedback for employees.

headline: How to Fly V.I.P., Perk by Perk
summary: Not an elite flier? You can still travel like one, for a price.

headline: Apple’s Stash of Credit Card Numbers Is Its Secret Weapon
summary: Apple now has 400 million active accounts in iTunes with credit cards. That means that all of Apple’s iOS devices are linked to those credit cards, too, challenging Google Wallet and others in the race to become a smartphone payment method.

headline: Investor Group Buys Orange County Register and Other Newspapers
summary: The group led by Aaron Kushner, a 39-year-old entrepreneur based in the Boston area, is buying several newspapers from Freedom Communications.

headline: Apple Steps Further Into the Business Market
summary: Apple’s new releases are usually sold for their effect on consumers and educators. With iPhones and iPads increasingly making their way into offices, however, and cloud computing blurring the line between work and home, Apple is becoming an enterprise device company, too. Some of the new features show how.

headline: The Two Keys to Investing: Pickiness and Persistence
summary: Buy good things and stay in them a long time. Investing success is as simple as that – and ignoring all of the noise around you.

headline: Apple Keeps Loyalty of Mobile App Developers
summary: Apps have become one of the strongest weapons for marketing mobile technologies to consumers and Apple is seeking to strengthen ties with app developers, who find that creating software for its smartphones is easier and more lucrative.

headline: Banks Look to Burnish Their Images by Backing Green Technology Firms
summary: Facing bad publicity, big banks are highlighting what has quietly become a hot growth area in recent years — backing so-called green companies and renewable energy projects.

headline: Google Outsells, but Apple Cultivates Loyalty of App Developers
summary: Apps have become vital in marketing mobile technologies to consumers, and the allegiance of app developers to Apple has helped propel the success of its devices.

headline: Wising Up to Facebook
summary: The thrill is gone, and that is a good thing for us and maybe for the future of social media, too.

headline: Tracking Viewers From TV to Computer to Smartphone
summary: Two pilot tests, conducted by Arbitron and comScore, are intended to demonstrate that it is possible to measure consumption of video content across various platforms.

headline: On ‘Good Morning America,’ Robin Roberts Reveals Bone Marrow Disorder
summary: She learned of her condition, she said Monday morning, during a time of personal high points — including improved ratings for her show, and an interview with President Obama.

headline: Health Law Ruling Won’t Alter Plans by Insurer
summary: UnitedHealth says it will continue offering some of the popular consumer protections required by the federal health care law, even if the Supreme Court strikes down the entire law later this month.

headline: Q&A: Finding Coordinates on Google Maps
summary: Unveil the coordinates of a location on a Google Map with a right-click of the mouse.

headline: Driving Miss Siri
summary: What Apple’s cooperation with automakers means for in-car electronics systems.

headline: The 20 Million
summary: Why is it that farmworkers, animals, even vegetables get more attention than food workers?

headline: Daughters of Boomers Giving More Financial Help to Parents, Study Finds
summary: Female baby boomers are also more likely to have financial conversations than men.

headline: The Return of Goldman’s Mark Schwartz
summary: After leaving Goldman in 2002, the banker worked for George Soros and later formed an investment firm with Raj Rajaratnam and Rajat K. Gupta.

headline: Verizon Unveils Wireless Plans That Cover Several Devices
summary: Verizon said its shared plans would become available to customers this month. The new plans will allow customers to pay monthly fees to share data, voice minutes and text messages across multiple devices, like smartphones, tablets and notebooks.

headline: Ads Promise You’ll Fall in Love With Cape Cod (Chips)
summary: A campaign for Cape Cod kettle-cooked chips is called the first for the brand that includes television and social media.

headline: Wheelies: The Eyes-Free Edition
summary: Major automakers have committed to integrating a button onto their vehicles’ steering wheels to summon Siri, Apple’s voice-command program.

headline: Justice Department Is Said to Investigate Cable Companies Over Internet Video
summary: At issue is whether caps on Internet data use imposed by cable companies are anticompetitive because they limit access to online video — and thus force consumers to have cable subscriptions.

headline: Powerade’s Olympics Campaign Puts Its Trust in ‘Nameonics’
summary: The sports drink’s theme, “power through,” has the benefit of reinforcing the name of the product — a strategy known as “nameonics.”

headline: Digital Notes: Plans for a New .Music Suffix, but Who Will Own It?
summary: The question of who should control the .music suffix is the latest example of the music world’s struggle over the Internet, as industry groups and technology giants compete.

headline: Prosecutors Draw ‘Secret Pipeline’ Pattern; Defense Asks, ‘Where’s the Beef?’
summary: Closing statements were heard in the trial of Rajat K. Gupta, the highest profile individual to be ensnared by the government’s insider trading crackdown.

headline: The Breakfast Meetings: Movies for People Like Us, and Major on Murdoch
summary: Also, there were worse-than-expected layoffs at The Times-Picayune and three Alabama newspapers, and The Huffington Post introduces a digital magazine named, of course, Huffington.

headline: British Officials Try Again on Google Data Collection
summary: For the third time, Google is being investigated in Britain over its secret Street View data collection. One thing investigators want to know: When they went to Google’s offices in 2010 and saw a prepared sample of the data, why didn’t it look anything like what they now know was collected?

headline: Jury Gets Insider Case of Ex-Goldman Director
summary: In final statements in the trial of the former Goldman director Rajat K. Gupta, prosecutors tried to connect the dots among reams of evidence but defense lawyers said there was no evidence of wrongdoing.

headline: Frito-Lay Takes New Tack on Snacks
summary: Frito-Lay said it would begin to emphasize the extremes of the snack-food market, pursuing both the customers who crave premium products and those who shop for cheaper items.

headline: Blankfein Speaks on Europe, the Financial Industry and Dimon
summary: The Goldman Sachs chief also throws cold water on suggestions that it might be time for him to retire: “I am 57. What am I going to do with the other 60 years of my life?”

headline: Google Wants Love and 100 Other Things
summary: Google proved to be one of the more ambitious applicants for new top level domain names, announced today. It applied for more than 100 domains, including .google, .youtube, .goog and .plus. It was the only applicant for .fly, .new and .eat. But it is going to have to fight Microsoft for .docs and .live, and Amazon for 17 top-level domains: .search, .shop, .drive, .free, .game, .mail, .map, .movie, .music, .play, .shop, .show, .spot, .store, .talk, .you and — bizarrely –.wow.

headline: CNN Is Ending John King’s Political Show
summary: The program’s failure to pick up a devoted audience reflects CNN’s problems in general as it struggles to attract viewers during quiet news periods.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Questions for Prime Minister, and Can Bieber Ever Grow Up?
summary: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain testifies about the relationship between the British press and government, subscriptions to Time Inc. magazines will be available via Apple’s newsstand, and the inspiration of the Martin Scorsese film “Goodfellas” died on Tuesday.

headline: Regulator May Grant Foreign Banks Brief Reprieve on Derivatives
summary: In a speech to bankers, the head of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission outlined a plan to regulate overseas derivatives trading while delaying some rules for foreign banks.

headline: Canada Seeks Alternatives to Transport Oil Reserves
summary: As oil companies complain of lost revenues, the government is moving forward with plans to build more pipelines of its own.

headline: Adding .app to the Internet
summary: Starting next year, the organization that oversees the naming system for Internet addresses is expected to approve hundreds of domain names with .app, the most sought-after extension.

headline: Time Inc. to Sell Its Magazines on Apple’s Newsstand
summary: Changing direction, Time Inc. will now work along with Apple to put its magazines on tablets and other devices.

headline: Guest Column: Yes, Oil Prices Are Cyclical
summary: With the shale oil boom promising over one million barrels a day of new oil production within a year in the United States, analysts are coming out of the woodwork to embrace falling oil prices. But all this is part of a normal cycle.

headline: Shifting the Paradigm for Training Racehorses
summary: The image of horses performing dressage movements at Saratoga Race Course might have seemed somewhat incongruous if interest in applying the principles of dressage to the training of thoroughbreds, both for racing as well as for their potential postracing careers, wasn’t growing steadily.

headline: On Facebook? So Are Your Future In-Laws
summary: Social networks have become the new snooping grounds for arranged marriages in India.

headline: McConnell Accuses Obama and Aides of Schemes to Curtail Free Speech
summary: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky on Friday accused President Obama, his campaign and his administration of engaging in tactics similar to those of the Nixon White House.

headline: Spanish Cost of Borrowing Soars After Rating Cut
summary: European leaders faced increasing pressure to respond as Spanish bond yields hit 7 percent, a level that has prompted full bailouts of other nations.

headline: Picking The Best Target-Date Mutual Fund
summary: Readers debate the merits of the target-date mutual funds that their employers have picked to put in their 401(k) or other workplace retirement plans.

headline: Rajat Gupta Convicted of Insider Trading
summary: Rajat K. Gupta, the retired head of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company and a former Goldman Sachs board member, is the most prominent executive convicted in the government’s sweeping investigation into insider trading on Wall Street.

headline: Sports Illustrated to Cut Editorial Staff
summary: Sports Illustrated is cutting editorial staff just weeks before the start of the Olympics and has asked reporters and editors to volunteer for buyout packages by June 21.

headline: The Safest Bank
summary: Taxpayers should love Citigroup even if shareholders don’t. And, on the bank’s 200th birthday, here’s why.

headline: Target-Date Funds Not Equally Safe
summary: Not all target-date funds are the same. Some are heavily into stocks, while others are more conservative and mainly in bonds.

headline: T.V. Ratings for Finals Up Seven Percent From Last Year
summary: The first two games of the N.B.A. Finals have so far attracted more viewers than any finals since ESPN and ABC’s current deal with the league began in 2002-03, according to Nielsen.

headline: Going Online to Check In, Not Check Out
summary: The technology world is divided into two camps: the wave of services that urge you to come online and stay a while, and the services that want you to use them, then log off.

headline: Niagara Falls Tightrope Walk Is a Ratings Bonanza for ABC
summary: The daring stunt by Nik Wallenda netted 13.1 million viewers in the final half hour, according to preliminary ratings, and easily surpassed other networks for the night.

headline: How to Read a Racist Book to Your Kids
summary: Many children’s classics are also highly offensive. Does that mean you should skip them altogether?

headline: C.E.O. Pay Is Rising Despite the Din
summary: Although more companies have given their shareholders say-on-pay votes, median compensation still climbed by 5 percent last year among the United States’ 200 top-paid chief executives.

headline: Mapping, and Sharing, the Consumer Genome
summary: Few consumers may have heard of Acxiom, a database marketer. But it has amassed the world’s largest commercial data trove about them, analysts say.

headline: Royalties From Digital Radio Start to Add Up
summary: On Monday, SoundExchange, a nonprofit group that processes payments for online streams, will announce that it has paid $1 billion to artists and record companies since its founding in 2000.

headline: Web Sites Illuminate Unknown Artists
summary: ArtistsWanted.org is not a charity but a business, one that hopes to make a profit identifying artistic talent and connecting it to an audience.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: When Buffett Is Your Boss
summary: Also, David Carr on the new Huffington Post, Apple takes on Google Maps and micropayments for music start to add up.

headline: Extending the Drama of Track and Field Year Round
summary: A sport that is a highlight of the Summer Games, track and field, will probably not raise its profile beyond the closing ceremonies, but its new chief executive wants to change that.

headline: Bieber Fever Comes to Macy’s
summary: For buying $168 (plus tax) worth of his new fragrance, 500 lucky fans received tickets for a show at the Apollo on Monday night.

headline: Digital Media’s Ever-Swifter Incursion
summary: In just one week, developments solidified the future of a new kind of media, with The Huffington Post and Time Inc. both announcing new tablet offerings.

headline: Goldman Stuck With a Defense Tab, and Awaiting a Payback
summary: Goldman Sachs must continue to pay Mr. Gupta’s bills until the case is completely resolved, a process that could take a couple of years.

headline: Verifying Ages Online Is a Daunting Task, Even for Experts
summary: Recent sexual assaults on children by adults who pretended to be minors on Skout, a mobile social networking app, has highlighted the challenge of verifying ages online.

headline: Newspaper Work, With Warren Buffett as Boss
summary: Three years after saying he would not buy a newspaper at any price, Warren Buffett has moved aggressively into the business, buying 63 papers and taking a 3 percent stake in Lee Enterprises.

headline: Apple’s Maps Don’t Look So Bad
summary: Side-by-side comparisons of Apple’s mobile map and Google maps have been moving around the Internet, and Apple’s map looks terribly light on information by contrast. That is not the final product, though. Apple skinned data off the maps it showed developers. The question is, why?

headline: Romantic Mishaps in Web-Size Bites
summary: Yahoo! Screen is challenging YouTube with original comedy programming like “Burning Love” (a “Bachelor” parody) and “First Dates With Toby Harris” (about dysfunctional encounters).

headline: Facebook Shifts Its Approach to Payments
summary: Facebook signaled its ambitions to grow as a payment platform, with changes to how its users can buy goods and services without leaving its site. It is also a clear signal to Wall Street that the company is pushing to make more money.

headline: Google Responds to New British Investigation of Street View
summary: For the third time, Google is being investigated by the British privacy regulators over its secret Street View data collection. This week, Google responded to authorities’ questions — but the controversy seems unlikely to be resolved quickly.

headline: Lil Wayne Defends Pulling Nicki Minaj From Hot 97’s Summer Jam
summary: The New Orleans rapper says “no person that works with me will be disrespected in my presence as long as I’m on this planet.”

headline: Electronics Retailers Scramble to Adapt to Changing Market
summary: Sales at physical electronics stores have declined an average of 2.6 percent a year in the last five years, while sales online have risen an average of 14.7 percent a year in that period.

headline: Free Speech for Computers?
summary: Free speech for computers is not science fiction. It’s a real issue that threatens consumers.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Assange Seeks Asylum and Debating ‘Free’ Music
summary: Also, a decline in Nook sales and News Corporation is in a buying mood again.

headline: Venice Beach Bodybuilders Fear Google Is Kicking Sand at Them
summary: A leasing spree by Google that includes a fabled gym has raised fears of a culture clash in the Los Angeles beach community of Venice, where the likes of Arnold Schwarzenegger have trained.

headline: Penney’s Gay Wager
summary: A major retailer has decided that a pro-gay image is worth anti-gay protest.

headline: Peter Thiel Opens a New Venture Capital Firm
summary: Peter Thiel has opened a new venture capital firm, Mithril Capital Management, with a $402 million fund.

headline: Debit Cards on Campus
summary: School-issued debit cards may come with hidden fees and other strings. Congress needs to take a hard look at how banks disburse financial aid to students.

headline: From Penguin, a Plan to Make Its E-Books Available in New York City Libraries
summary: The publisher, in conjunction with city libraries and 3M, will make its books available in e-format, though they will not be available immediately after release.

headline: Figuring Out a Better Way to Train Employees
summary: That’s the life of the small-business owner: you think you have made it to the next level, and then you realize that it’s not a particularly secure position and you need to open your wallet again to try to keep from falling back.

headline: Washington Mutual’s Former Chief Takes Issue With Book’s Portrayal
summary: Kerry K. Killinger, the bank’s chief executive until his ouster in 2008, is taking issue with a new book about Washington Mutual.

headline: Good Features Demand Good Design
summary: Manufacturers have to weigh the desire to have devices do a lot of things against the simplicity that consumers demand — and deserve. They keep loading on features that drag down a product’s usefulness rather than adding to it.

headline: Smartphones: The New Post-Coital Cigarette?
summary: Americans are addicted to their smartphones. The latest confirmation comes from a Harris Interactive survey of more than 2,000 smartphone owners, which shows the first thing Americans do after sex is reach for their cellphone. Twice that many said they couldn’t use the bathroom without them.

headline: Q&A: Playing Music on a Kindle Reader
summary: Amazon Kindle e-readers can also play music, as long as the files are in the right place and the right format.

headline: At Google’s Annual Meeting, Silence From Larry Page
summary: Google’s co-founder and chief executive, Larry Page, is generally a man of few words. He had even fewer of them Thursday — none, to be exact — when a voice ailment compelled him to skip the company’s annual meeting.

headline: Pandora Faces Rivals for Ears and Ads
summary: The playlist app Songza and the digital music service called Spotify, the latest challengers to Pandora, have prompted warnings from analysts about the possible effects these updates will have on Pandora.

headline: Novel Maneuvers in Battle for Quest Software
summary: The bidding war that has emerged for Quest Software highlights a board’s quandary when the chief executive makes a play for the company: whose rights should triumph, those of the majority shareholder or all shareholders?

headline: City Issues Warnings as It Prepares for Second Day of Heat
summary: With temperatures expected to hit 98 degrees on Thursday, the city opened 455 air-conditioned cooling centers and asked schools to limit outdoor recess for students.

headline: Aiming for the Time and Place Right Before That Queasy Feeling
summary: A new campaign for Dramamine is directed at summer vacationers, focusing not on the suffering but on beautiful views from cars, planes and ships.

headline: The Travelers Remains the Tour’s Proving Ground
summary: The Travelers Championship has succeeded by developing relationships with the next generation of stars and providing them with sponsor exemptions.

headline: As Facebook Seeks Answers, S.E.C. Investigates Exchanges
summary: Investor confidence in the markets has waned after problems on the day Facebook shares began trading.

headline: Google Aims to Smooth the Path for Android Developers
summary: Android is the top operating system in mobile, but Android app developers don’t seem to be making much money compared to Apple iOS developers. Google is trying to change that.

headline: A.I.G. Installs New Chairman at Plane-Leasing Unit
summary: The American International Group said on Thursday that it had named a new executive chairman of its plane-leasing unit following an investigation into a relationship between the division’s chief executive and another employee.

headline: How Hot Is It?
summary: Day 2 of the summer’s first hot spell toppled a record for the date at Kennedy International Airport, but power use did not appear headed for record highs and Con Edison reported few customers without power. Please send us your weather-related observations.

headline: Market Ready
summary: A desirable view is blocked by window air-conditioners. Is installing through-the-wall-air-conditioning units worth the trouble before selling?

headline: Frances W. Preston, Defender of Songwriters’ Copyright, Dies at 83
summary: Ms. Preston, head of the BMI music licensing group for two decades, was described as the highest-ranking woman in the music industry when she retired.

headline: EBay Plans Data Center That Will Run on Alternative Energy Fuel Cells
summary: The center would make eBay the first major tech company to use alternative power as a primary source for such facilities.

headline: Health Groups Criticize Allergy Drug Promotion
summary: The health advocates contend Merck is improperly marketing the allergy medicine directly to children by using characters from the movie “Madagascar 3: Europe’s Most Wanted.”

headline: The Best and Brightest
summary: Italo Zucchelli, the designer for Calvin Klein, explains how a single item from a designer’s collection can catch the public’s fancy and blows up. In his case, it was neon suits.

headline: Flipboard, Another Apple Darling, Expands to Android

headline: A Sober New Reality in Credit Downgrades for Banks

Johnson, as head of the combined company.

summary: James P. Hackett of Steelcase observes that good leaders “have this sense of peace, this self-awareness, that says, ‘I understand who I am.’”

headline: AT&T’s FaceTime Restrictions Could Be Violating F.C.C. Rules

AT&T, however, will allow that only for customers on a shared data plan, which has raised debate on whether the carrier is violating government net neutrality rules.

headline: Account of ‘a Lynch’ in Jerusalem on Facebook
summary: An eyewitness to the beating of a young Palestinian by Israelis in Jerusalem last week posted an account on Facebook.

headline: Apple Becomes the Most Valuable Public Company Ever, With an Asterisk

On Monday it became the most highly valued public company ever, breaking the record for the highest market capitalization set by Microsoft. But Microsoft still holds the record when its 1999 value is adjusted for inflation.

summary: David O. Sacks, the chief executive of Yammer, who recently sold his business to Microsoft for $1.2 billion, is suddenly bearish on start-ups. On Saturday, he wrote on Facebook: “I think Silicon Valley as we know it may be coming to an end.”

headline: Best Buy’s Tough Earnings May Lift Schulze’s Hopes a Little

summary: The trade publication will soon introduce the most significant redesign in years to its weekly print product, redirecting its editorial focus in a digital world from breaking news to analysis.

summary: Buoyed by a legal victory, Apple shares reached a record high before closing at $675.68 even as volume dropped ahead of a speech by the Federal Reserve chairman.

summary: Chipotle Mexican Grill rounds change in some markets, to avoid handling coins that might slow down the checkout process.

summary: Ms. Perry, known for songs like “California Gurls,” “Firework” and “Teenage Dream,” is becoming a minority investor in Popchips Inc. as well as a spokeswoman.

summary: The event designer for the Venice Film Festival shares his favorite places with T.

summary: Increases in commercial rents in Manhattan have led a range of technology companies to leave hipper neighborhoods for cheaper rents in Midtown.

summary: GSV, the largest of several closed-end mutual funds that offer ordinary investors a chance to own stakes in privately held companies, has been hit particularly hard by Facebook’s troubles.

summary: Washington may soon be home. Wolfeboro, N.H., may become the Summer White House. But for now, the Tampa Marriott Waterside Hotel is Camp Romney, with its quirks and hierarchies on full display.

summary: Environmental advocates and community groups worry that a proposed natural gas pipeline in the Rockaways could damage fragile ecosystems, create safety hazards and compromise Brooklyn’s only piece of national parkland.

summary: Plaintiffs in the lawsuit, settled for $590 million, said the bank failed to disclose its huge holdings in collateralized debt obligations.

summary: Muve Music has built one of the largest subscriber bases in the business by going after young users who exclusively use their phones to go online.

headline: New York State Is Investigating Energy Drink Makers
summary: New York is looking at whether the makers of energy drinks are misleading consumers about how much caffeine the drinks contain and the health risks they could pose.

The idea is to offer companies social tools that could enhance productivity. It may also be a way to raise the profile of Google Plus, which has over 100 million users, but little buzz.

headline: Potluck for the Eyeballs: Amazon’s Streaming Service

headline: Is This Thing On? Yahoo Firing Proves the Perils of Feeding Many Platforms
